questions.text: Nociceptors have their cell bodies located in which of the following structures?

options.label: B
options.text: Ventral horn of the spinal cord

questions.text: Feedforward Inhibition is seen in
questions.explanation:
Feature

Feedback Inhibition

Feedforward Inhibition

Definition

Inhibition where the output of a process inhibits its own production.

Inhibition where an excitatory neuron directly inhibits another neuron in response to input.

Mechanism

The end product of a metabolic pathway inhibits an enzyme involved in the pathway.

An excitatory neuron activates an inhibitory neuron and then inhibits a downstream neuron.

Function

It helps maintain homeostasis by regulating the production of substances.

Anticipates and prevents excessive excitation in neural circuits.

Example

The inhibition of an enzyme in a metabolic pathway by its end product (e.g., ATP inhibiting phosphofructokinase).

In the cerebellum, excitatory inputs inhibit output neurons to prevent overexcitation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of events at the neuromuscular junction?

options.label: A
options.text: Ca2+ influx → ACh release → End-plate potential → Muscle contraction

options.label: B
options.text: ACh release → Ca2+ influx → End-plate potential → Muscle contraction

options.label: C
options.text: End-plate potential → Ca2+ influx → ACh release → Muscle contraction

options.label: D
options.text: ACh release → End-plate potential → Ca2+ influx → Muscle contraction

questions.correct_answer: A. Ca2+ influx → ACh release → End-plate potential → Muscle contraction

questions.text: Slow Type inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP) is generated by?
questions.explanation:
IPSP Type

Channel

Region

Slow IPSP

Opening of K+ Channel (Option A)

Autonomic ganglia, smooth muscles, cardiac muscles.

Fast IPSP

Entry of Cl- Channel (Option C)

All parts of the CNS.

questions.text: During the generation of excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP), which of the following movements of ions occur at the postsynaptic membrane?
Which subtype of GABA receptors mediate fast inhibitory postsynaptic potentials through the entry of Cl- into neurons? GABA-A GABA-B GABA-C
questions.explanation:
Type

Receptor subtype

Subunit

Distribution

Mechanism

Inotropic receptor

GABA- A

Pentamers of various combinations: 6 α, 4 β, 4 γ, 1 δ, 1 ε

CNS

Activation allows Cl– entry into neurons, mediating fast inhibitory postsynaptic potentials (IPSP)

GABA- C

Pentamers of three ρ subunits in various combinations

Almost exclusively in the retina.

G-protein coupled receptor

GABA- B

No specific subunit composition

CNS

Linked via G-proteins: Gi inhibits adenylyl cyclase to open the K+ channel, Go inhibits or delays Ca2+ influx.

questions.text: Match the following neurotransmitters with their site of production in CNS. A. Acetylcholine (ACh) 1. Raphe nuclei B. Norepinephrine (NE) 2. Nucleus basalis of Meynert C. Dopamine 3. Locus ceruleus D. Serotonin 4. Substantia nigra
questions.explanation:
Neurotransmitters

Source

Description

Acetylcholine (ACh)

Nucleus basalis of Meynert
  • Associated with Muscle contraction, Memory and REM sleep
  • NT* for Sweat glands

Norepinephrine (NE)

Locus ceruleus

Regulates wakefulness and alertness.

Dopamine

Substantia nigra
  • Destruction causes Parkinson’s disease.
  • NT* of reward and addiction.

Serotonin

Raphe nuclei
  • Regulation of mood, sleep, and appetite.
  • The highest concentration is in Platelets, enterochromaffin cells, and myenteric plexus.

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is primarily responsible for inhibiting motor neuron activity at the level of the spinal cord to regulate muscle tone and reflexes?
Which protein, essential for regulating neurotransmitter release at the neuromuscular junction, prevents the premature fusion of synaptic vesicles?
Which of the following types of vesicle at the synaptic terminal contain glutamate neurotransmitter ?
questions.explanation:
Types of vesicles

Neurotransmitters

Small clear vesicles

Acetylcholine, GABA, glutamate

Small dense core vesicles (Option C)

Catecholamines(eg:dopamine,epinephrine and norepinephrine)

Large dense core vesicles (Option B)

Neuropeptides

questions.text: Identify the correct statement about the neospinothalamic tract for pain:

options.label: A
options.text: It primarily carries slow pain sensations

options.label: B
options.text: The first-order neurons terminate mainly in lamina II of the dorsal horn

options.label: C
options.text: The neurotransmitter released by the Aδ fiber is glutamate

options.label: D
options.text: All fibers terminate exclusively in the reticular formation

questions.correct_answer: C. The neurotransmitter released by the Aδ fiber is glutamate
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Reference:
  • ↳ Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 615, 616
  • ↳ G. K Pal Comprehensive Textbook of Medical Physiology, 1st Edition, Page 1017, 1018

Aspect

Description

Fiber Type

Aδ (A-delta) fibers

Function

Carries fast pain sensations, primarily mechanical and acute thermal pain (Option A ruled out)

First-Order Neurons

Terminate mainly in lamina I of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord (Option B ruled out)

Second-Order Neurons
  • Cross to the opposite side of the spinal cord through the anterior commissure.
  • Ascend in the anterolateral pathway.
  • The fibers terminate mainly in the ventrobasal complex, and a few fibers also terminate in the posterior nuclear complex of the thalamus.
  • Sparse projections to midbrain reticular formation, periaqueductal grey and hypothalamus (Option D ruled out)

Third-Order Neurons
  • Originate from specific thalamic nuclei.
  • The signals are then transmitted to other basal areas of the brain as well as somatosensory cortex

Localization of Pain
  • Fast pain is better localised than slow-chronic pain.
  • Exact localisation requires simultaneous stimulation of tactile receptors

Neurotransmitter

Glutamate (primary neurotransmitter at Aδ fiber endings) (Option C)

Topographic Organization

In spinal cord:

  • Lower body fibers placed laterally
  • Upper body fibers placed medially
  • Sacral segment fibers occupy most lateral part
  • Cervical segment fibers occupy most medial part

 

Special Features

Pain perception persists despite removing somatic sensory areas of the cerebral cortex, indicating that the brain stem, thalamus, and lower centers handle this function. The cortex only helps in interpreting pain quality, not perception.

questions.text: Which of the following nuclei has a function of thermoregulation?
Which of the following best explains why rods are more sensitive to low light than cones?
questions.correct_answer: B. High convergence onto ganglion cells

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is primarily involved in fast pain?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Reference:
  • ↳ Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 158

 

Fast pain (First Pain)

Slow pain (Second Pain)

Fiber Type

Aδ fiber

  • Myelinated
  • Large diameter (2-5 µm)

C fiber

  • Unmyelinated
  • Smaller diameter (0.4 - 1.2 µm)

Location

Body surface

Deeper tissues

Conduction velocity

Very rapid (~12- 35 m/s)

Very slow (~ 0.5 - 2 m/s)

Neurotransmitter

Glutamate (Option B)

Substance P (Option A Ruled out)

Description

  • Rapid response
  • Mediates the discriminative aspects of pain (localisation and intensity)

Delayed, dull, intense, diffuse and unpleasant feeling associated with noxious stimulus

questions.text: Which of the following statements about climbing and mossy fibers is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Climbing and mossy fibers provide the primary input to the cerebellar cortex

options.label: B
options.text: The Vestibulocerebellar serves as the pathway for climbing fibers.

options.label: C
options.text: Mossy fibers are the terminal endings of the olivocerebellar tracts.

options.label: D
options.text: Mossy fibers use aspartate to provide excitatory signals to the Purkinje cells.

questions.correct_answer: A. Climbing and mossy fibers provide the primary input to the cerebellar cortex
questions.explanation:
Source/Tracts

Fiber Type

Neurotransmitter

Function

Olivocerebellar tracts

Climbing Fibers

Aspartate

Proprioceptive input from the entire body

Vestibulocerebellar

Mossy Fibers

Glutamate

Receives information from the labyrinth.

Spinocerebellar

Mossy Fibers

Glutamate

Receives information from the Muscle spindle, the Golgi Tendon Organ.

Cuneocerebellar

Mossy Fibers

Glutamate

Receives information from the Muscle spindle, Golgi Tendon Organ.

Tectocerebellar

Mossy Fibers

Glutamate

Receives information from visual & auditory.

Pontocerebellar

Mossy Fibers

Glutamate

Receives information from the motor & other parts of the cerebral cortex.

questions.text: Which statement correctly describes the effect of each basal ganglia pathway?

options.label: A
options.text: The direct pathway decreases inhibitory output from the internal segment of the globus pallidus.

options.label: B
options.text: The indirect pathway decreases inhibitory output from the internal segment of the globus pallidus.

options.label: C
options.text: The direct pathway increases inhibitory output from the external segment of the globus pallidus.

options.label: D
options.text: The indirect pathway increases inhibitory output from the external segment of the globus pallidus.

questions.correct_answer: A. The direct pathway decreases inhibitory output from the internal segment of the globus pallidus.
questions.explanation:
Direct Pathway

Indirect Pathway

Function

Facilitates motor activity

Suppresses motor activity

Input

Excitatory input from the cerebral cortex

Excitatory input from the cerebral cortex

Target

Striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen)

Striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen)

Striatum Output

Inhibits internal segment of globus pallidus (GPi)

Inhibits external segment of globus pallidus (GPe)

GPi/SNr Effect

Reduced inhibition of thalamus

Increased inhibition of thalamus

Thalamus Effect

Increased thalamic activation

Decreased thalamic activation

Motor Cortex Effect

Enhanced motor activity

Reduced motor activity

Subthalamic Nucleus (STN)

Not directly involved

Activated by reduced inhibition from GPe

questions.text: Which type of receptor is most likely responsible for detecting the rapid changes in pressure and vibrations in the patient's fingertips?
questions.explanation:
Rapidly Adapting Tactile Receptors

Structure

Function

Location

Adaptation

Pacinian Corpuscle
(Option B)

Encapsulated nerve ending
  • Detect tissue vibration or other rapid changes in the mechanical state of tissues
  • Stimulated by rapid local compression of the tissue

Immediately beneath the skin and deep in the fascial tissues of the body

Adapts in a few hundredths of a second

Meissner Corpuscle
(Option A ruled out)

Elongated, encapsulated nerve ending of a large myelinated sensory nerve fiber
  • Sensitive to movement of objects over the skin and low-frequency vibrations
  • crucial for spatial location discernment of touch sensations

Non-hairy skin, particularly abundant in fingertips and lips.

Adapts in a fraction of a second

Hair End Organ (Option C ruled out)

Nerve fiber entwined at the base of each hair

Detects :

  • Movement of objects on the body surface or
  • Initial contact with the body

Hairy skin

Adapts readily

questions.text: Which law explains the phenomenon of phantom limb pain?

options.label: A
options.text: Muller's Doctrine of Specific Nerve Energy

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding removal of each somatosensory area is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Somatosensory Area I: complete loss of pain and temperature sensations.

options.label: B
options.text: Somatosensory Area II: inability of precise localization of sensations

options.label: C
options.text: Somatosensory Association Areas: inability to recognize two sides of an object

options.label: D
options.text: Somatosensory Area I: enhance ability to judge the shape of an object

questions.correct_answer: C. Somatosensory Association Areas: inability to recognize two sides of an object
questions.explanation:
Feature

Somatosensory Area I
(SSA 1)

Somatosensory Area II (SSA 2)

Somatosensory Association Area

Location

Postcentral gyrus (Brodmann's areas 3, 1, and 2).

Superior wall of Sylvian fissure

Brodmann's areas 5 and 7, located in parietal cortex behind SSA I

Representation and localisation
  • High localization of body parts.
  • Nose, lips, mouth and face laterally; head, neck, shoulder and lower body part medially
  • Poor localization (Option B)
  • Face is represented anteriorly, arms centrally and legs posteriorly

Combines information from the primary somatosensory area, leading to complex sensations, such as feeling an object like a knife or ball.

Function

Primary area for somatic sensation

Less known functions; Relies on input from SSA I

Decipher deeper meanings of sensory information from SSA

Sensory Information

Receive inputs from thalamic and cortical areas

Signals enter from brain stem, SSA I and from other sensory areas (visual and auditory)

Receives signals from SSA I, thalamus,visual cortex and auditory cortex

Effect of Excision

B/L excision of leads to:

  1. Loss of precise localization of sensations
  2. Inability to judge pressure against the body, weight, texture, or shape of the object (astereognosis) (Option D).
  3. Pain and temperature senses preserved but poorly localized (Option A)

Removal of parts of SSA II does not affect the response of neurons in SSA I

U/L removal leads to:

  1. Amorphosynthesis: Difficulty recognizing objects on one side. (Option C)
  2. Hemineglect: Denial of the existence of the opposite side of the body.
  3. Constructional apraxia: Difficulty in constructing a picture.

questions.text: Which layer of the cerebral cortex is primarily responsible for receiving input sensory signals and sending them to other layers?
questions.explanation:
Layer

Function

I- Molecular layer

Receives nonspecific input signals from lower brain centers.
Control the excitability of stimulated areas.

II- External granular layer

Receives nonspecific input and sends axons to the opposite cortex through the corpus callosum.

III- External pyramidal layer

Sends axons to related cortical areas on the opposite side through the corpus callosum.

IV- Internal granular layer

The primary layer for receiving input sensory signals, which then spread to the surface and deeper layers.

V- Internal pyramidal layer

Sends large axons to distant nervous system parts like basal ganglia, brain stem, and spinal cord.
Controls signal transmission.

VI- Fusiform/ polymorphic layer

Sends axons to the thalamus.

Regulates excitability of incoming sensory signals.

questions.text: Which of the following parts of the brain is responsible for working memory?
Which of the following statements about EEG (Electroencephalogram) is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: EEG measures the summated version of EPSP and IPSP generated in the brain.

options.label: B
options.text: EEG records the dendritic potentials of pyramidal neurons.

options.label: C
options.text: Positive dendritic potentials are known as EPSP (Excitatory Postsynaptic Potential) and negative dendritic potentials are known as IPSP (Inhibitory Postsynaptic Potential).

options.label: D
options.text: D) Electrocorticography (ECOG) is the measurement of electrical activity specifically in the cerebral cortex by placing electrodes on the surface of scalp.

questions.correct_answer: D. D) Electrocorticography (ECOG) is the measurement of electrical activity specifically in the cerebral cortex by placing electrodes on the surface of scalp.
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ EEG Function: Records electrical activity from the brain's surface, detecting dendritic potentials, not action potentials. EEG Components: Captures the summated EPSPs and IPSPs. Pyramidal Neurons: Major contributors to the signals detected by EEG.
  • ➤ EEG Function: Records electrical activity from the brain's surface, detecting dendritic potentials, not action potentials.
  • ➤ EEG Components: Captures the summated EPSPs and IPSPs.
  • ➤ Pyramidal Neurons: Major contributors to the signals detected by EEG.
  • ➤ Pyramidal Neurons:
  • ➤ Electrocorticography (ECOG): Involves placing electrodes directly on the cerebral cortex, not over the scalp, to measure electrical activity.
  • ➤ Electrocorticography (ECOG):

Arrange in order the mechanism of sound transmission i) Depolarization of hair cells ii) Bending of stereocilia iii) Production of neurotransmitter glutamate iv) K & Ca enter via the channel
